segment.source: 5154(S) The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.
segment.target: 5154(S) The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 5154(S) The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.
segment.target: Describes security event 5154(S) The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.

segment.source: 5154(S): The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.
segment.target: 5154(S): The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time Windows Filtering Platform permits an application or service to listen on a port.
segment.target: This event generates every time Windows Filtering Platform permits an application or service to listen on a port.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Application Information:
segment.target: Application Information:

segment.source: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which was permitted to listen on the port.
segment.target: Process ID Type = Pointer: hexadecimal Process ID of the process which was permitted to listen on the port.

segment.source: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.
segment.target: Process ID (PID) is a number used by the operating system to uniquely identify an active process.

segment.source: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):
segment.target: To see the PID for a specific process you can, for example, use Task Manager (Details tab, PID column):

segment.source: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.
segment.target: If you convert the hexadecimal value to decimal, you can compare it to the values in Task Manager.

segment.source: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.
segment.target: You can also correlate this process ID with a process ID in other events, for example, “4688: A new process has been created” Process InformationNew Process ID.

segment.source: Application Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.
segment.target: Application Name Type = UnicodeString: full path and the name of the executable for the process.

segment.source: Logical disk is displayed in format deviceharddiskvolume.
segment.target: Logical disk is displayed in format deviceharddiskvolume.

segment.source: You can get all local volume numbers by using diskpart utility.
segment.target: You can get all local volume numbers by using diskpart utility.

segment.source: The command to get volume numbers using diskpart is “list volume”:
segment.target: The command to get volume numbers using diskpart is “list volume”:

segment.source: Network Information:
segment.target: Network Information:

segment.source: Source Address Type = UnicodeString: local IP address on which application requested to listen on the port.
segment.target: Source Address Type = UnicodeString: local IP address on which application requested to listen on the port.

segment.source: IPv4 Address
segment.target: IPv4 Address

segment.source: IPv6 Address
segment.target: IPv6 Address

segment.source: :: - all IP addresses in IPv6 format
segment.target: :: - all IP addresses in IPv6 format

segment.source: 0.0.0.0 - all IP addresses in IPv4 format
segment.target: 0.0.0.0 - all IP addresses in IPv4 format

segment.source: Source Port Type = UnicodeString: source TCPUDP port number which was requested for listening by application.
segment.target: Source Port Type = UnicodeString: source TCPUDP port number which was requested for listening by application.

segment.source: Protocol Type = UInt32: protocol number.
segment.target: Protocol Type = UInt32: protocol number.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: 6 – TCP.
segment.target: 6 – TCP.

segment.source: 17 – UDP.
segment.target: 17 – UDP.

segment.source: More information about possible values for this field: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc959827.aspx.
segment.target: More information about possible values for this field: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc959827.aspx.

segment.source: Filter Information:
segment.target: Filter Information:

segment.source: Filter Run-Time ID Type = UInt64: unique filter ID which allows application to listen on the specific port.
segment.target: Filter Run-Time ID Type = UInt64: unique filter ID which allows application to listen on the specific port.

segment.source: By default Windows firewall won't prevent a port from being listened by an application and if this application doesn’t match any filters you will get value 0 in this field.
segment.target: By default Windows firewall won't prevent a port from being listened by an application and if this application doesn’t match any filters you will get value 0 in this field.

segment.source: To find specific Windows Filtering Platform filter by ID you need to execute the following command: netsh wfp show filters.
segment.target: To find specific Windows Filtering Platform filter by ID you need to execute the following command: netsh wfp show filters.

segment.source: As result of this command filters.xml file will be generated.
segment.target: As result of this command filters.xml file will be generated.

segment.source: You need to open this file and find specific substring with required filter ID (filterId), for example:
segment.target: You need to open this file and find specific substring with required filter ID (filterId), for example:

segment.source: Layer Name Type = UnicodeString: Application Layer Enforcement layer name.
segment.target: Layer Name Type = UnicodeString: Application Layer Enforcement layer name.

segment.source: Layer Run-Time ID Type = UInt64: Windows Filtering Platform layer identifier.
segment.target: Layer Run-Time ID Type = UInt64: Windows Filtering Platform layer identifier.

segment.source: To find specific Windows Filtering Platform layer ID you need to execute the following command: netsh wfp show state.
segment.target: To find specific Windows Filtering Platform layer ID you need to execute the following command: netsh wfp show state.

segment.source: As result of this command wfpstate.xml file will be generated.
segment.target: As result of this command wfpstate.xml file will be generated.

segment.source: You need to open this file and find specific substring with required layer ID (layerId), for example:
segment.target: You need to open this file and find specific substring with required layer ID (layerId), for example:

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 5154(S): The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.
segment.target: For 5154(S): The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections.

segment.source: If you have a “whitelist” of applications that are associated with certain operating systems or server roles, and that are expected to listen on specific ports, monitor this event for “Application Name” and other relevant information.
segment.target: If you have a “whitelist” of applications that are associated with certain operating systems or server roles, and that are expected to listen on specific ports, monitor this event for “Application Name” and other relevant information.

segment.source: If a certain application is allowed to listen only on specific port numbers, monitor this event for “Application Name” and “Network InformationSource Port.”
segment.target: If a certain application is allowed to listen only on specific port numbers, monitor this event for “Application Name” and “Network InformationSource Port.”

segment.source: If a certain application is allowed to listen only on a specific IP address, monitor this event for “Application Name” and “Network InformationSource Address.”
segment.target: If a certain application is allowed to listen only on a specific IP address, monitor this event for “Application Name” and “Network InformationSource Address.”

segment.source: If a certain application is allowed to use only TCP or UDP protocols, monitor this event for “Application Name” and the protocol number in “Network InformationProtocol.”
segment.target: If a certain application is allowed to use only TCP or UDP protocols, monitor this event for “Application Name” and the protocol number in “Network InformationProtocol.”

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined application which should be used to perform the operation that was reported by this event, monitor events with “Application” not equal to your defined application.
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined application which should be used to perform the operation that was reported by this event, monitor events with “Application” not equal to your defined application.

segment.source: You can monitor to see if “Application” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).
segment.target: You can monitor to see if “Application” is not in a standard folder (for example, not in System32 or Program Files) or is in a restricted folder (for example, Temporary Internet Files).

segment.source: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in application names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Application.”
segment.target: If you have a pre-defined list of restricted substrings or words in application names (for example, “mimikatz” or “cain.exe”), check for these substrings in “Application.”

segment.source: Typically this event has an informational purpose.
segment.target: Typically this event has an informational purpose.
